item.title: Krafton Introduces Voluntary Redundancy Scheme Following "AI First" Announcement
item.content:encoded:
PUBG and Subnautica 2 publisher Krafton has introduced a voluntary redundancy program just a couple of weeks after announcing that it intended to be an "AI first" company.

As spotted by news platform Business Korea, the studio is offering resignation support to employees who decide to take voluntary redundancy, paying up to 36 months' salary depending on duration of employment. Even those who have been with Krafton for a year or less are being included in the program; they're being offered six months' salary to take redundancy.

Krafton itself says the goal with this program is to support employees in "proactively designing their growth direction" and that staffers will be given the choice to "continue the direction of change internally or expand externally", which sounds like a pretty classic piece of corporate-ese to me.

According to Business Korea, Krafton insists that its program is not a way to reduce its workforce, although CFO Bae Dong-geun did confirm this month that hiring has been frozen at the company, exempting "organizations developing original intellectual property and AI-related personnel".

News of Krafton's voluntary redundancy program comes after the company posted a revenue increase of 21% on a year-on-year basis this quarter and 31.5% on a quarter-by-quarter basis. Operating profit has also increased both year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter, and Krafton's main IP, PUBG, has grown as well.

Unfortunately, studios firing employees despite recent successes isn't a new thing in the gaming industry, and as the widespread push for AI continues, this isn't a situation that's likely to change significantly anytime soon.

Krafton's redundancy program also comes after the company became embroiled in a legal battle with former Subnautica 2 developers following their dismissal from subsidiary Unknown Worlds, a battle that still rages on at time of writing.

Whatever your stance on generative AI may be (and there are a number of opinions among industry bodies), one thing's for sure: Krafton is going all-in on the technology. Stay tuned for more.
